document.ModsDocTitle: A review of the Nearctic genus Zealeuctra Ricker (Plecoptera, Leuctridae), with the description of a new species from the Cumberland Plateau region of eastern North America
document.docAuthor: Grubbs, Scott A., Kondratieff, Boris C., Stark, Bill P. & DeWalt, R. Edward
document.masterDocTitle: A review of the Nearctic genus Zealeuctra Ricker (Plecoptera, Leuctridae), with the description of a new species from the Cumberland Plateau region of eastern North America

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: A review of the Nearctic genus Zealeuctra Ricker (Plecoptera, Leuctridae), with the description of a new species from the Cumberland Plateau region of eastern North America

subSubSection.paragraph: Zealeuctra talladega Grubbs, 2005: 40. Holotype ♂ (INHS), tributary to Barbaree Creek, 22 km E Talladega, Clay Co., Alabama

Male - abdominal tergal cleft. Anterior portion is near parallel-sided, U-shaped, and broadly rounded along anterior margin (Figs 7 A-C ). Posterior portion is somewhat V-shaped and sinuous along inner margins, posterior terminus marked by either a single (Fig. 7C) or paired (Figs 7 A- 8B) medially-directed subtriangular projections. Crenulations absent from inner margins of cleft..

Female - 7th sternum. Seventh sternum with a small, lobe nested in a scarcely-convex central notch. Lobe ranges in shape from subtriangular (Fig. 7G) to convex (Fig. 7H). Posterior margin moderately convex.

caption.paragraph: Figures 7. Zealeuctra talladega , scanning electron micrographs, USA, Alabama, Clay Co., tributary to Swept Creek, 24 January 2006 ( A-B , D-E , G), USA, Alabama, Clay Co., tributary to West Fork Hatchet Creek, 25 January 2006 (C, F, H). A-C male, cleft, dorsal view, 350 x D-F male, epiproct, lateral view, 500 x G-H female, posteromedial portion of seventh abdominal sternite, 350 x .

subSubSection.paragraph: This species is known only from the southern Talladega Mountains region of eastern Alabama (Fig. 13), the southern terminus of the Appalachian Moun tains . Extensive collecting efforts by both the author and Dr. Andrew Sheldon since 2005 have yet to produce localities north from the two counties (Clay and Talladega) where this species has been obtained.
